statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following } \\ \quad f(x) = e^{x^3} \\ \text{with respect to x.}\\

step.context: \textbf{Right or wrong? } \text{If }f(x) = e^{g(x)},\text{ then}\\ \frac{d}{dx}f(x)\text{ equals the following.}
step.reason: \begin{align} \text{If }f(x) &= e^{g(x)},\text{ then }\\ \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \underbrace{\dfrac{d}{d g(x)}e^{g(x)}\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x)}_{\text{Chain Rule}}\\ &= e^{g(x)}\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \end{align} \\ \textbf{Alternatively, } \\ \begin{align} f(x) = e^{g(x)} \implies \log f(x) &= g(x)\cdot\underbrace{\log e}_{=1} \\ \implies \dfrac{d}{dx}\log f(x) &= \dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \\ \implies\dfrac{1}{f(x)}\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \\ \implies \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \underbrace{e^{g(x)}}_{ = f(x) }\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \end{align}
